Empires & Puzzles Fated Summon 7 (July 2025): The Ultimate Guide & Best Picks

The July 2025 Fated Summon refresh brings a mix of Musketeers, Magic Tower wizards, and some dust-gathering Season 4 heroes. While the power creep gap is widening, gems like Aramis and Cardinal Richelieu still offer immense value. Here is your roadmap to navigating the list.
Fated Summon 7: Musketeers, Magic, and Hard Choices
Fated Summon 7: The "Good, The Bad, and The Glitched" Edition
The Fated Summon reset for July 21, 2025, has arrived (or is just about to), and it brings a roster that has the community divided. On one hand, we finally have access to the
heroes without chasing abysmal portal odds. On the other hand, with the current stats of modern heroes pushing 1300+ power unlimit-broken, many of these options are showing their age.

This refresh was also marked by a chaotic start where a "glitch" allowed a chunk of the player base to claim all 20 heroes instantlyâ€”a moment that will surely live in E&P infamy. For the rest of us playing by the rules (or who slept through the chaos), we have 100 summons to fill the bar and a tough choice to make.
none of these heroes come with their costumes
, which significantly impacts the value of the Season 4 and Magic options.
Here is the lineup for Fated Summon 7:
Cardinal Richelieu, Athos, Porthos, Constance, Aramis
If you are looking for immediate impact, these are the heroes that stand the test of time despite the stats gap.
Aramis was the king of his meta, and his kit remains incredibly relevant. He provides

for 3 turns, which is a hard counter to the endless DoT and status-effect heavy defenses we see today. Combined with a heal (boosted based on damage dealt) and the Musketeer passive "Cover" ability, he keeps your team alive. Even with older stats, his utility is top-tier.
The Cardinal is a menace. He summons Spy Fiends that not only absorb healing but
from the enemy at the end of each turn. In a meta full of taunts, dodge, and massive buffs, a passive buff stealer is invaluable. He disrupts the enemy's rhythm simply by existing.
Magic heroes are flexible, and Vaishali offers two distinct, high-value tools. On her first charge (Magic speed), she
all allies and gives an attack boost. On her second charge, she
all enemies and applies Sand damage. A fast cleanser is always needed for war depth, and her versatility makes her a safe, strong pick.
, destroys all minions from the target

hitting, and bypasses defensive buffs (including counterattack). He hits hard and fast. While his stats aren't what they used to be, a Very Fast sniper who ignores defense buffs is always useful for picking off threats in Wars or Tournaments.
Even without his costume (which makes him a tank beast), base Xnolphod has a unique niche:

. He heals and gives 10% mana to all allies. This mana bump can be the difference between your slow heroes firing or dying. He is a tile manipulator (Dark) as well, making him a staple for Purple stacks.
These heroes serve a specific purpose. If you have the Top 5 or specific roster gaps, look here.
A Fast speed yellow sniper who also hits a random second target and applies Defense Down. Excellent for
and Mythic Titans due to the defense drop.
A Slow blue hero who hits all and alters Ice shields. His value lies almost entirely in
teams where tile alteration can lead to massive scores.

Like Vaishali, she is flexible. Charge 1 boosts health and gives defense against specials. Charge 2 reduces enemy max health. She is a solid support hero, though often overshadowed by more aggressive healers.
A weird but fun hero. Very Fast speed, steals all buffs, and steals mana. She deals no damage, which makes her tricky, but she can completely neuter a taunt hero or a slow nuker if timed right.

Great for DoT (Damage over Time) teams. He increases the damage enemies take from status ailments. If you run heroes like Narcisa or heavy bleed/burn/poison dealers, he amplifies their output significantly.
Unless you are a collector or simply love their design, these heroes struggle to find a place in the modern game.

Often cited as one of the worst 5-star heroes. Her mechanic relies on heavy tile presence to do damage, and it's easily cleansed or blocked. Even community tests often skip her because she offers so little threat.

He goes into "Ghost" form, healing himself and boosting ally defense, but he does nothing offensive. In today's fast-paced meta, a passive hero who just "survives" while his team dies around him is often a liability.

Skargremar, Areax, and Uthragan suffer from "average" syndrome. Their stats were average on release, and now they are low. Skargremar's accuracy debuff is okay, and Areax hits decently hard if he can chain, but they don't bring the unique utility of the Musketeers or Magic heroes.

Her first charge is weak (damage + conditional mana cut), and her second charge (very slow effectively) relies on allies casting skills to deal damage. It's too much setup for too little payoff compared to other purples.
This is easily the strongest row in this Fated Summon. The Musketeer passive (Cover) provides damage mitigation and counter-damage, which is excellent for survivability.
are arguably better than any hero in the other rows. If you are undecided, pick from this row.
The Magic family passive (chance to deal damage or drop mana stacks) is subtle but annoying. The real value here is the
(Charge 1). Having heroes that can fire in 5-6 tiles to cleanse (Vaishali) or heal (Camilla) is vital for War attacks. They require more finesse to use than the Musketeers but offer great depth.
Season 4 heroes have fallen behind significantly. Without their costumes (which boost stats and update skills), most are hard to justify.
are the exceptions due to their specific utility (Mana/Def Down).
is a decent damage dealer but requires a heavy red board to shine, making him inconsistent compared to modern nukers.
HOTMs generally have lower stats and simpler skills than event heroes.
is the only one with a truly unique mechanic (Mana Steal) that can't be found easily elsewhere.
offers healing reduction, which can be useful, but generally, this row offers the least value for your precious 100 summons.
Emblem & Strategy Tips for the Winners
Defense/Health. You want him to survive to cast his immunity. His damage is secondary to his buff.
Pairs beautifully with slow heroes or healers. His "Cover" passive protects squishier allies.
Attack/Defense. His fiend damage scales off attack, and you want those fiends biting hard.
Great against heavy buffers like Arco, Hathor, or Ludwig.
Defense/Health. He is a tank/support. His job is to live and feed mana.
Put him next to slow rush heroes (like Alfrike or Khufu) to bridge the gap in mana generation.
. He is a game-changer for roster depth.
. He makes fighting buff-heavy teams fun.

The exclusion of costumes for the older heroes (S4 especially) has been a major point of contention. Many players feel that base Season 4 heroes are simply "food" at this stage of the game. However, for Free-to-Play (F2P) or C2P players, gaining access to the Musketeer passive mechanics is a significant win. Don't let the lack of costumes deter you from grabbing the unique utility provided by the Musketeers and Magic heroes.
